title: Getting Around Mexico
subtitle: Complete Transportation Guide: Flights, Buses, Cars & More
meta_title: Mexico Transportation Guide - Flights, Buses, Rental Cars & Getting Around
meta_description: How to get around Mexico: domestic flights, luxury buses, car rentals, Uber, taxis, and local transport. Complete guide to traveling between and within Mexican cities.
hero_alt: Mexican highway with scenic mountain views
introduction: Mexico is a massive country—almost three times the size of Texas. Getting around efficiently requires understanding your options: budget airlines connect major cities in hours, luxury buses rival first-class flights, rental cars offer freedom, and ride-sharing apps have revolutionized urban transport. Here's everything you need to know about moving through Mexico.

sections.title: Domestic Flights
sections.content:
**Budget Airlines:**
- **Volaris:** Mexico's largest budget carrier. Cheap base fares, but everything extra (bags, seats, snacks) costs more. Book directly on their website for best prices.
- **Viva Aerobus:** Ultra-low-cost carrier. Rock-bottom prices if you travel light. Frequent sales.
- **VivaAerobus & Volaris tips:** Book 4-8 weeks ahead, fly Tuesday-Thursday, avoid holidays.

**Full-Service Airlines:**
- **Aeroméxico:** Mexico's flag carrier. Better service, included bags, more routes. Codeshares with Delta.
- **Aeroméxico Connect:** Regional routes to smaller destinations.

**Booking Tips:**
- Compare all airlines—prices vary wildly by route and date
- Budget airlines have strict weight limits (usually 10-15kg carry-on, 25kg checked)
- Book directly with airline to avoid third-party issues
- Arrive 2 hours early for domestic flights

**Sample Flight Times:**
- Mexico City to Cancún: 2.5 hours
- Mexico City to Oaxaca: 1 hour
- Guadalajara to Los Cabos: 2 hours
- Cancún to Mexico City: 2.5 hours

sections.title: Long-Distance Buses
sections.content:
**Mexico's Secret Weapon:** First-class Mexican buses are genuinely excellent—often better than flying for medium distances. Reclining seats, WiFi, movies, bathrooms, and no airport hassle.

**Bus Classes:**
- **Primera Plus/ETN (Ejecutivo):** The best. Fully reclining seats (like business class), 2+1 configuration, snacks, individual screens. Worth the premium.
- **ADO GL/Platino:** Similar luxury for routes in southern Mexico.
- **Primera (First Class):** Comfortable, 2+2 seating, AC, bathroom. The standard for tourist routes.
- **Segunda (Second Class):** Local buses, frequent stops, budget option. Fine for short trips.

**Major Bus Companies:**
- **ADO:** Dominates southern Mexico (Yucatán, Oaxaca, Chiapas, Veracruz). Excellent.
- **ETN/Primera Plus:** Central and western Mexico (CDMX, Guadalajara, Guanajuato). Top quality.
- **Estrella Blanca:** Northern routes.
- **Pullman de Morelos:** Cuernavaca, Taxco routes.

**Booking:**
- Book online at ADO.com.mx, PrimeraPlus.com.mx, or ETN.com.mx
- Or buy at bus stations (TAPO, Norte, Sur in Mexico City)
- Reserve 1-2 days ahead for popular routes, same-day usually fine otherwise

**Sample Bus Times & Prices:**
- Mexico City to Oaxaca: 6-7 hours, $30-50 USD (first class)
- Cancún to Mérida: 4-5 hours, $20-35 USD
- Mexico City to Guanajuato: 5 hours, $35-55 USD
- Guadalajara to Puerto Vallarta: 5 hours, $25-40 USD

sections.title: Rental Cars
sections.content:
**When to Rent:**
- Road trips (Baja California, Yucatán Peninsula, Pacific Coast)
- Exploring ruins and cenotes independently
- Visiting multiple small towns
- When buses don't go where you want

**When NOT to Rent:**
- Mexico City (traffic, parking nightmare, Uber is better)
- Beach resort stays (taxi/shuttle cheaper than parking + insurance)
- If you're uncomfortable with aggressive driving styles

**Rental Tips:**
- **Book in advance** from home through major companies (Hertz, Avis, Budget, National)
- **Get full insurance:** Mexican liability laws are different. Get the CDW (collision damage waiver) and liability coverage. Your US insurance and credit cards usually DON'T cover Mexico.
- **Inspect thoroughly:** Document every scratch with photos before leaving the lot
- **Use toll roads (cuotas):** They're safer, faster, and well-maintained. Worth the cost.
- **Don't drive at night:** Poorly lit roads, animals, potholes, and in some areas, security concerns.
- **Carry cash for tolls:** Most toll booths don't take cards

**Costs:**
- Economy car: $25-45 USD/day
- Full insurance: Add $15-30 USD/day
- Gas: Similar to US prices (~$1/liter)
- Tolls: $5-40 USD depending on route

**Gas Stations:** Pemex is the main chain (recently joined by others). Full service—attendants pump gas. Tip 10-20 pesos.

sections.title: Uber, DiDi & Ride-Sharing
sections.content:
**The Revolution:** Ride-sharing has transformed Mexican travel. Safer, cheaper, and no haggling compared to street taxis.

**Available Apps:**
- **Uber:** Available in most major cities and tourist areas. The go-to option.
- **DiDi:** Chinese competitor, often slightly cheaper than Uber. Growing coverage.
- **Cabify:** Premium option, available in major cities.
- **InDriver:** Negotiate your fare. Popular in some regions.

**Where They Work:**
- Mexico City ✓
- Guadalajara ✓
- Cancún (limited, not in Hotel Zone) ✓
- Playa del Carmen ✓
- Puerto Vallarta ✓
- Oaxaca ✓
- Mérida ✓
- Los Cabos (limited) ✓
- Smaller towns: Usually no coverage

**Tips:**
- Download apps and set up accounts before arrival
- Link a card that works internationally (no foreign transaction fees)
- Check if your phone works in Mexico (or get local SIM)
- Cash option available but card is easier
- Cancún Hotel Zone restricts Uber—use taxis or hotel shuttles there

**Costs:** Typically 30-50% cheaper than taxis. A 20-minute ride in Mexico City: $3-6 USD.

sections.title: Taxis
sections.content:
**Types of Taxis:**
- **Sitio taxis:** From official stands (taxi ranks). Safest option. Fixed prices posted.
- **Libre taxis:** Hailed on street. Riskier, especially at night. Negotiate price first.
- **Radio taxis:** Called by phone. Safe, reliable, slightly more expensive.
- **Hotel taxis:** Arranged by hotel. Safest but most expensive.
- **Airport taxis:** Prepaid at official booths inside terminals. Fixed prices by zone.

**Safety Rules:**
- NEVER hail a taxi on the street at night
- Use Uber/DiDi when possible
- In Mexico City, ONLY use sitio, radio, or app taxis
- If using street taxi, take photo of license plate and send to friend
- Agree on price BEFORE getting in (or confirm they'll use meter)

**Avoiding Scams:**
- Ask your hotel what a fair price should be
- 'No hay cambio' (no change) is often a lie—carry small bills
- If meter runs suspiciously fast, something's wrong
- Don't accept 'special tours' or 'my friend's restaurant'

**Tipping:** Not required but round up to nearest 10 pesos for good service.

sections.title: City Metro & Public Transit
sections.content:
**Mexico City Metro:**
- One of the world's busiest (5M+ daily riders)
- Incredibly cheap: 5 pesos per ride (~$0.30 USD)
- Covers most tourist areas
- Avoid rush hour (7-9am, 6-8pm)—it's PACKED
- Women/children cars available during peak hours
- Watch for pickpockets
- Download official Metro map app

**Mexico City Metrobús:**
- Bus rapid transit on dedicated lanes
- Faster than regular buses, cheaper than Uber
- Covers routes Metro doesn't
- Buy rechargeable card at stations

**Other City Transit:**
- **Guadalajara:** Light rail + buses. Efficient.
- **Monterrey:** Metro system. Clean and modern.
- **Mérida:** Buses only, but city is very walkable.
- **Most beach towns:** Taxis, colectivos, or walking.

**Colectivos (Shared Vans):**
- Ubiquitous throughout Mexico
- Fixed routes, very cheap ($0.50-2 USD)
- Hail them on the street, pay driver
- Say 'baja' when you want to get off
- Great for short distances in smaller towns

sections.title: Ferries & Boats
sections.content:
**Cozumel Ferry:**
- From Playa del Carmen to Cozumel
- Operators: Ultramar, Winjet (similar quality)
- 45 minutes, ~$15 USD each way
- Runs every 1-2 hours
- Book online or at pier (same price)
- Can be rough—take motion sickness meds if sensitive

**Isla Mujeres Ferry:**
- From Cancún (Puerto Juárez or Hotel Zone) to Isla Mujeres
- 15-20 minutes, ~$10-15 USD each way
- Frequent departures
- Puerto Juárez is cheaper than Hotel Zone ferries

**Holbox Ferry:**
- From Chiquilá to Isla Holbox
- 20 minutes, ~$10 USD each way
- Leaves when full (usually every 30 min)

**Baja California Ferry:**
- Baja Ferries: La Paz to Topolobampo or Mazatlán
- Long crossing (6-18 hours depending on route)
- Cars can cross too
- Book in advance for vehicle spots

**Water Taxis:**
- Common for beach-hopping (Yelapa, Las Caletas from Puerto Vallarta)
- Negotiate prices at the pier
- Usually $15-30 USD for day trips

sections.title: Airport Transfers
sections.content:
**Options at Major Airports:**

**Official Airport Taxi:**
- Prepaid at booths inside terminal (after customs)
- Fixed prices by zone, posted clearly
- Safe and reliable but most expensive option
- Cancún to Hotel Zone: $50-80 USD
- Mexico City to Centro: $15-25 USD

**Shared Shuttles:**
- Companies like SuperShuttle, USA Transfers
- Shared van, multiple hotel stops
- Cheaper than private but slower
- Book online in advance
- Good for solo travelers on budget

**Private Transfers:**
- Book through hotel, tour company, or services like Cancun Airport Transportation
- Meet-and-greet with name sign
- Best for families or groups
- Worth it for peace of mind
- Can arrange car seats for children

**Uber at Airports:**
- Technically available at some airports but complicated
- Mexico City: Works but use designated rideshare pickup
- Cancún: Uber banned in Hotel Zone, limited elsewhere
- Other airports: Check locally

**ADO Bus from Cancún Airport:**
- Goes to Playa del Carmen, Tulum, downtown Cancún
- $10-15 USD, comfortable
- Good budget option if traveling light

sections.title: Tips by Region
sections.content:
**Yucatán Peninsula (Cancún, Tulum, Mérida):**
- Rent a car for cenotes and ruins exploration
- ADO buses excellent between cities
- Colectivos for Playa-Tulum corridor (cheap!)
- Uber works in Playa, limited in Cancún

**Mexico City:**
- Don't rent a car—traffic is brutal, parking scarce
- Uber/DiDi are your friends
- Metro for longer distances during off-peak
- Walking best in Roma, Condesa, Centro

**Oaxaca:**
- City is walkable
- Hire drivers for day trips to Monte Albán, Hierve el Agua
- ADO for coast (6-7 hours to Puerto Escondido)
- Flights save time to coast

**Baja California:**
- Rent a car—essential for road trip
- Few buses between towns
- Highways excellent
- Long distances—plan driving days

**Pacific Coast:**
- Buses connect major cities well
- Rent car for exploring between towns
- Flights save time on long stretches
- Colectivos in towns

sections.title: Money-Saving Tips
sections.content:
**Flights:**
- Set flight alerts on Google Flights or Skyscanner
- Fly Tuesday-Thursday for lowest prices
- Budget airline sales can be incredible (book fast)
- Check both Cancún and Mexico City as hubs

**Buses:**
- Book online for 10-20% discounts sometimes
- Travel overnight to save on hotels
- First class is worth it for long trips (comfort = sleep)
- Student/senior discounts sometimes available

**Rental Cars:**
- Book way in advance for best rates
- Compare all pickup locations (airport usually pricier)
- Week-long rentals often cheaper per day
- Return with full tank to avoid inflated refueling fees

**Urban Transport:**
- Uber/DiDi always cheaper than taxis
- Metro is incredibly cheap (but crowded)
- Walk when possible—Mexican cities are very walkable
- Colectivos for budget travel between nearby towns

**General:**
- Combine destinations to minimize backtracking
- Sometimes flying saves money vs. multiple buses
- Ask hotels about transportation—they often have deals

faqs.question: Is it safe to drive in Mexico?
faqs.answer: Daylight driving on main highways and toll roads is generally safe. Avoid driving at night (poor lighting, animals, and in some areas security concerns). Toll roads (cuotas) are much safer than free roads (libres). Get full insurance. Some areas have travel advisories—check current state department guidance for your route.

faqs.question: Should I rent a car or use buses?
faqs.answer: Depends on your trip. Rent a car for: Baja road trips, cenote hopping in Yucatán, exploring small towns, or when you want flexibility. Use buses for: City-to-city travel on main routes, when you want to relax, or in Mexico City where driving is stressful. Many travelers combine both.

faqs.question: How do I get from Cancún airport to Tulum?
faqs.answer: Options from cheapest to most convenient: 1) ADO bus ($15-20, 2+ hours, drops at Tulum town—not beach), 2) Shared shuttle ($25-35, multiple stops), 3) Private transfer ($80-120, direct to hotel). For the beach zone hotels, private transfer is usually worth it as public transit doesn't go there.

faqs.question: Is Uber safe in Mexico?
faqs.answer: Yes, Uber is considered safer than street taxis in Mexico. You have a record of the trip, driver info, and digital payment. It's widely used by locals and tourists. The main limitations are coverage (not available everywhere) and some areas like Cancún Hotel Zone where taxis have blocked Uber.
